text.p: United Technologies Corp's aero engine unit Pratt & Whitney and its French partner Snecma on Wednesday detailed plans, first announced this April, to create a range of powerplants for regional passenger jets.

The overall engine outline has now been defined and presented to customers, Pratt & Whitney Canada president David Caplan told a news conference at the Farnborough airshow, and the two firms "believe the market potential is significant".
However, he predicted that the venture would proceed with preparatory work without any specific orders from planemakers in mind until some time towards the middle of next year.

"The programme is geared to be able to deliver less than three and a half years from 'Go' -- and we'd expect a 'Go' from the middle of next year. That is, somebody would roll out an order probably at the time of the Paris airshow," Caplan added.
The three-and-a-half year timeframe would be "well within the customers' requirements", he said, adding that the exact timetable for production would be dictated by the marketplace.

Caplan stressed that the turbofan engine range, designated SPW14, would not be a derivative of any existing product and would be "the first engine specifically designed for the regional market by anyone".
The family of engines will be in the 12,000 to 16,000 pound thrust range, for regional aircraft in the 58 to 90 passenger range, the firms said in a joint statement.

Asked where he saw the likely market, Caplan replied that the alliance anticipated several thousand aircraft would require such engines, with leading prospects including Europe's AI(R) consortium and planemakers on "the Pacific rim".

Citing what many aerospace suppliers here have described as an increasingly demanding customer environment, Caplan said the engine was meant to set "new industry standards" in fuel consumption, reliability and maintenance cost.
He said he believed that a guaranteed performance of 10,000 hours "out of the box" was the sort of level needed by the regional market, where aircraft usage is normally intense.
